How web typography has evolved

  • 12 June 2024
  • chat

Typography

Responsive typography

We've gone from one screen resolution to accommodating standard mobile and tablet sizes to no assumptions about viewport size or pixel density. We've seen various shifts:

  • px to rems. Once hotly debated. The 62.5% trick of converting 1 rem to 10 px is still quite popular.
  • Media queries to fluid typography (with viewport units and calc). Recommended: The Utopia CSS generator and Trys Mudford's video presentation about Utopia and fluid design. Utopia also helps us with type scale.
  • individually spaced elements to systems for flow (vertical stacking). Recommended: The stack on Every Layout and this typography demo by Mike Mai on Ben Myer's someantics.dev.
  • New units: ch, ex, vw, vh, vmin and vmax.

Accessibility

We have seem an increased awareness that the web should be readable to all:

  • From a western bias to writing modes and internationalisation. We talk about this when discussing a talk by Rachel Andrew on modern CSS layout.
  • Web safe fonts to an abundance of open source options and back to quality and system fonts. We did a short video on system fonts which looked at modernfontstacks.com. Familiarity help users the most, but designers like new trends. We have to find a balance.
  • From the browser styles to setting line height and proximity according to the font used. WCAG can give us some guidelines (ie. 1.5 for paragraph line heights). Experts set this according to the font's "X" size. They know also to reduce the line height on headings and make the space above a heading wider the the space to the next paragraph for better proximity.
  • From seeing link underlining as "visual clutter" to respecting it as essential UI. We now have text underlining offset , text-decoration thickness and style giving designers more control.

Variable Fonts

  • Multiple font formats (TTF, OFT, EOT, WOFF) to WOFF2 (unless supporting IE).
  • Individually loading weights and italics to fine control via CSS.
  • Color (chromatic) fonts. It is probably too soon to see the value particularly as this has not started with one format.

Lesser used specifications

There's lots in HTML and CSS that is probably under-used in typography. Here we are using CSS columns to force two columns within the space available. We could set it to columns: 2; but we would need a media query for smaller devices. Instead this set to columns: 18rem auto; so when there is not 18rem of space it colapses to one column.

  • In the above section we are using :first-letter with initial-letter: 1.5 to create a drop cap.
  • On this site the <kbd></kbd> tag saves us needing images to explain keyboard commands Ctrl ⇧ Shift and Enter ↵
  • There's many other useful tags in HTML. In this article we have used: <abbr title="Web Content Accessibility Guidelines">WCAG</abbr> and used <wbr> to force the Typograpy title to break as "typo" and "graphy" when ther is not enough space.

New specifications

  • Hanging-punctuation It gives us the ability to have stop quotation marks indenting the text. Safari only.
  • font-size-adjustMost useful for ajusting fallback fonts to match custom fonts. Preventing a jump. Limited availability
  • font-kerning sets the use of the kerning information stored in a font. Auto lets the browser decide. Normal let the font decide. Fully supported.
  • background-clip sets whether an element's background extends underneath its border box, padding box, or content box. Used on the title of this post. Widely Available.

Typography

Branding & Storytelling

Designers have got ever more creative with text and the W3C is making it easier.

  • Scroll animation coming to CSS.
  • Writing modes.
  • Better positioning with CSS grid and subgrid.
  • Blending, filtering, masking and overlapping with other elements.
